Ransomware.Pandora: Pandora is a rebranded version of Rook ransomware. Researchers found that Pandora encrypts files and appends the “.pandora” extension to filenames. It provides a ransom note in the “Restore_My_Files.txt” file. The ransom note states that files are encrypted using the RSA-2048 algorithm. The price of the decryption tool depends on how fast victims will contact the attackers using the contact@pandoraxyz.xyz email address. The list of encrypted files can be reviewed using the provided Tor website.  Ransomware targets automotive giant DENSO. https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/automotive-giant-denso- hit-by-new-pandora-ransomware-gang/
Ransomware.RURansom: RURansom is a wiper. The malware is written in .NET programming language and spreads as a worm by copying itself under the file name in Russian to all removable disks and mapped network shares. Translated into English, the file name reads as “Russia-Ukraine_War-Update.doc.exe.” After successfully spreading, the malware then begins encryption. If the assigned disk letter is “C:\,” for example, the files in the folder “C:\\Users\\<UserName>” are encrypted. For other removable and mapped network drives, all files that recursively branch from the root directory are encrypted. Encryption is applied to all file extensions except for “.bak” files, which are deleted. The files are encrypted with a randomly generated key with length equal to base64 (“FullScaleCyberInvasion + “ + MachineName).  Ransomware targeting Russia. https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/22/c/new-ruransom-wiper-targets- russia.html
Ransomware.Stormous: Stormous is a ransomware used by the Stormous gang in their malicious campaigns for financial gain. Stormous ransomware notes are written in Arabic.  Stormous gang supports Russia https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/22/c/cyberattacks-are-prominent- in-the-russia-ukraineconflict.html
Ransomware.LokiLocker: LokiLocker is a ransomware family targeting English-speaking victims and Windows PCs; the threat was first seen in the wild in mid-August 2021. It shouldn’t be confused with an older ransomware family called Locky, which was notorious in 2016, or LokiBot, which is an infostealer. It shares some similarities with the LockBit ransomware (registry values, ransom note filename), but it doesn’t seem to be its direct descendant. LokiLocker encrypts victim’s files on local drives and network shares with a standard combination of AES for file encryption and RSA for key protection. It then asks the victim to email the attackers to obtain instructions on how to pay the ransom. LokiLocker also boasts an optional wiper functionality - if the victim doesn’t pay up in the timeframe specified by the attacker, all non-system files will be deleted and the MBR overwritten, wiping all the victim’s files and rendering the system unusable. With a single stroke, everyone loses. LokiLocker works as a limited- access Ransomware-as-a-Service scheme that appears to be sold to a relatively small number of carefully vetted affiliates behind closed doors. Each affiliate is identified by a chosen username and is assigned a unique chat-ID number.  | What is Loki Locker? New Ransomware Family Identified: LokiLocker RaaS Targets Windows Systems. https://blogs.blackberry.com/en/2022/03/lokilocker-ransomware

Malware.Owprox: Owprox (aka Owlproxy) is a Trojan malware associated withthe China-linked Slug.  | Malware OwlProxy Daxin: Stealthy Backdoor Designed for Attacks Against Hardened Networks. https://symantec-enterprise-blogs.security.com/blogs/threat-intelligence/daxin- backdoor-espionage
Malware.Daxin: Stealthy Backdoor Designed for AttacEmulov A Trojan used by China-linked threat actors, in addition to malware Daxin, in their malicious campaigns since at least 2019.  Daxin: Stealthy Backdoor Designed for Attacks Against Hardened Networks. https://symantec-enterprise-blogs.security.com/blogs/threat-intelligence/daxin- backdoor-espionage
Malware.AnchorDNS: As the name would indicate, the AnchorDNS backdoor hides C2 communication such as polling, commands, and command responses inside DNS.  | Malware Anchor DNS AnchorDNS: How TrickBot Malware Hides C2 Inside DNS Traffic and How to Turn the Tables https://www.ultimatewindowssecurity.com/webinars/register.aspx?id=3669
Malware.PowerTrick: PowerTrick is a PowerShell-based backdoor that is designed to execute commands and return the results in Base64 format, the system uses a generated UUID based on computer information as a “botID.”  | Information on Power Trick Trickbot Group’s AnchorDNS Backdoor Upgrades to AnchorMail https://securityintelligence.com/posts/newmalware-trickbot-anchordns- backdoor-upgrades-anchormail/
Malware.IssacWiper: IsaacWiper is found in either a Windows DLL or EXE with no Authenticode signature; it was discovered on February 24th, 2022. The oldest PE compilation timestamp found was October 19th, 2021, meaning that if its PE compilation timestamp was not tampered with, IsaacWiper might have been used in previous operations months earlier.  | What do you know about Isaac Wiper? Wiper deployed by Russia to attack Ukrainian devices. https://www.welivesecurity.com/2022/03/01/isaacwiper-hermeticwizard-wiper- worm-targeting-ukraine/
Malware.SunSeed: SunSeed is a Lua-based malware. Based on decoding of the SunSeed print.lua malicious second stage payload script, it appears to be a simple downloader that obtains the C Drive partition serial number from the host, appends to a URL request via a Lua socket, consistently pings the C2 server for additional Lua code, and executes the code upon receiving it within a response.  | Malware Sun Seed State Actor Uses Compromised Private Ukrainian Military Emails to Target European Governments and Refugee Movement https://www.proofpoint.com/us/blog/threatinsight/asylum-ambuscade-state- actor-uses-compromisedprivate-ukrainian-military-emails
Malware.Soul: The backdoor is a DLL dropped to the disk by a simple dropper. The dropper LZMA- decompresses the backdoor and a configuration that they both share. The dropper writes the backdoor to a path specified by the configuration and appends the configuration to it as an overlay. Depending on the command-line argument passed to the dropper, the backdoor is executed with LoadLibrary or rundll32.exe. Finally, the dropper deletes itself from the disk.  Unraveling the Evolution of the SoulSearcher Malware https://www.fortinet.com/blog/threat-research/unravelingthe-evolution-of-the- soul-searcher-malware
Malware.Rad: Rad is a modular espionage malware toolkit built around the POCO C++ cross- platform development libraries. The toolkit is associated with threat actor EGoManiac. The design entails a form of organized development but not a particularly savvy or sophisticated one at that. POCO is doing most of the heavy lifting. Functionality is split into modules contained within a ‘RadApplicationInstaller’ and orchestrated by a ‘RadStarter’ module that takes its cues from an encrypted configuration XML file.  | What is Rad Toolkit? Custom malware used by threat actor EGoManiac. https://www.sentinelone.com/labs/egomaniac-anunscrupulous-turkish-nexus- threat-actor/
Malware.SaintBot: The SaintBot tool is a downloader that allows the threat actors to download and run additional tools on the infected system. SaintBot provides the actors persistent access to the system while granting the ability to further their capabilities.  Spear Phishing Attacks Target Organizations in Ukraine, Payloads Include the Document Stealer OutSteel and the Downloader SaintBot. https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/ukrainetargeted-outsteel-saintbot/
Malware.WhisperKill: WhisperKill is designed to destroy and rename files in connected drives that match the file extensions. It then terminates and removes itself. WhisperKill enumerates drives A to Z and destroys files on drives that are either Type 3 (DRIVE_FIXED) or 4 (DRIVE_REMOTE). It is basically a malware downloaded by WhisperGate that destroys files with specific extensions.  | Whisper Kill Malware used by Russia to compromise devices in Ukraine. https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/22/c/cyberattacks-are-prominent- in-the-russia-ukraineconflict.html
Malware.MicroBackdoor: MicroBackdoor is a publicly available backdoor program developed using the C ++ programming language. It is known to be used by members of the group UAC-0051 / unc1151. The server part is designed using the Python programming language and provides a simple web interface for managing bots. Persistence: Run Windows Registry Key. Communication between the bot and the server is encrypted using RC4.  Backdoor used by threat actor UNC 1151 https://cert.gov.ua/article/37626
Malware.DEADEYE: DEADEYE is a backdoor that comes in multiple variants: 1) DEADEYE.DOWN has the capability to download additional payloads. 2) DEADEYE.APPEND has additional payloads appended to it. 3) DEADEYE.EXT loads payloads that are already present on the system.  Malware used by APT41. https://www.mandiant.com/resources/apt41-usstate-governments
Malware.BUMBLEBEE: BUMBLEBEE uses WMI to collect various system details such as OS version, user name, and domain name, which are then exfiltrated in JSON format to a C2. In response, it expects to receive one of the several supported “tasks”, which include execution of shellcode, dropping, and running executable files. At the time of the analysis, BUMBLEBEE was observed to fetch Cobalt Strike payloads.  Malware used by newly discovered threat actor group, EXOTIC LILY. https://blog.google/threat-analysis-group/exposing-initial-access-broker-ties- conti/
Malware.Klingon RAT: Klingon RAT is well-featured and resilient due to its multiple methods of persistence and privilege escalation. It was determined that the RAT is being used by cybercriminals for financial gain. It is important to stay on top of this threat as it will degrade Antivirus security by killing targeted processes and hiding communications through encrypted channels.  | What do you know about Klingon RAT? Threat active in July 2021, added in the KB. https://www.intezer.com/blog/malware-analysis/klingon-rat-holding-on-for- dear-life/
Malware.Stitch: Stitch is a Python-based malware that is available on GitHub. The attackers likely use this as a “throwaway” backdoor which they replace with something custom after identifying a victim of interest. Despite its availability on GitHub, this malware is not frequently used in the wild.  Threat active in March 2021, added in the KB. https://www.volexity.com/blog/2020/03/31/storm-cloud-unleashed-tibetan- community-focus-of-highly-targeted-fake-flash-campaign/
Malware.BrainDamage: BrainDamage is a Python-based malware family which is available on GitHub. It supports a wide range of functionality natively but in the same vein as STITCH, i.e., it is used as a throwaway backdoor.  Threat active in March 2021, added in the KB. https://www.volexity.com/blog/2020/03/31/storm-cloud-unleashed-tibetan- community-focus-of-highly-targeted-fake-flash-campaign/
Malware.Thor: Thor is a variant of malware PlugX. Researchers identified this PlugX variant delivered as a post-exploitation remote access tool (RAT) to one of the compromised servers. The variant observed was unique in that it contained a change to its core source code: the replacement of its trademark word “PLUG” to “THOR.” The earliest THOR sample uncovered was from August 2019, and it is the earliest known instance of the rebranded code. New features were observed in this variant, including enhanced payload-delivery mechanisms and abuse of trusted binaries.  | Thor Old threat, added in the KB. A variant of PlugX backdoor https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/thor-plugx-variant/
Malware.BlackBone: BlackBone is a riskware that is used to spy on vicitms.  | Can you tell me about Black Bone? A riskware, added in the KB. https://howtofix.guide/win64-riskware-hacktool-blackbone-a/
Malware.Scieron: Scieron is a custom backdoor used by the Chinese threat actor group Scarab.  Malware used by threat actor group Scarab. https://www.sentinelone.com/labs/chinese-threat-actor-scarab-targeting- ukraine/
Malware.MSIL: MSIL is a malicious trojan infection which uses malicious tricks to download nasty malware threats from the web.  Russian Ransomware Gang Retool Custom Hacking Tools of Other APT Groups. https://thehackernews.com/2022/03/russian-ransomware-gang-retool-custom. html
Malware.Verblecon: Verblecon is sufficiently complex and powerful for ransomware and espionage attacks although it is used for low-reward attacks. Verblecon was spotted earlier in the year 2022 and the known samples enjoy a low detection rate due to the polymorphic nature of the code. The researchers say that the end goal of whoever is behind Verblecon deployments is to install cryptocurrency mining software, which is not in tune with the effort required to develop malware of such sophistication.  Verblecon malware loader used in stealthy crypto mining attacks https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/verblecon-malware-loader- used-in-stealthy-crypto-mining-attacks/
Malware.CaddyWiper: CaddyWiper, the third wiper malware strain to hit Ukraine during the Russian invasion of Ukraine in 2022. CaddyWiper does not share any significant code similarity with HermeticWiper, IsaacWiper, or any other malware known. Similar to HermeticWiper deployments, researchers observed CaddyWiper being deployed via GPO, indicating the attackers had prior control of the target’s network beforehand. Interestingly, CaddyWiper avoids destroying data on domain controllers. This is probably a way for the attackers to keep their access inside the organization while still disturbing operations.  Third Wiper malware targeting Ukraine. https://twitter.com/ESETresearch/status/1503436420886712321
Malware.GrimPlant: GrimPlant malware is written in Go, a versatile and cross-platform programming language with minimal footprint and low AV detection rates. The capabilities of this tool cover network reconnaissance, command execution, and file operations. GrimPlant capabilities: 1) Gather IP address, hostname, OS, username, home dir. 2) Execute commands received remotely and return results to C2. 3) Use gRPC (HTTP/2+SSL) for C2 communication.  Fake antivirus updates used to deploy Cobalt Strike in Ukraine https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/fake-antivirus-updates- used-to-deploy-cobalt-strike-in-ukraine/
Malware.Gh0stCringe: Gh0stCringe, aka CirenegRAT, is a variant of Gh0st RAT malware that was most recently deployed in 2020 Chinese cyber-espionage operations but dates as far back as 2018. Gh0stCringe RAT is a powerful malware that establishes a connection with the C2 server to receive custom commands or exfiltrate stolen information to the adversaries. The malware can be configured during deployment with specific settings concerning its functions. Its keylogger is maybe the most aggressive component as this is what steals user inputs from the compromised system. The keylogging component uses the Windows Polling method (GetAsyncKeyState API) for querying the state of every key through an endless loop.  | CirenegRAT malware | Details on GhostCringe Unsecured Microsoft SQL, MySQL servers hit by Gh0stCringe malware https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/unsecured-microsoft-sql- mysql-servers-hit-by-gh0stcringe-malware/
Malware.Turian: Turian is a custom backdoor that is derived from the Quarian backdoor. The Turian network connection process follows a similar pattern to Quarian, attempting to make a direct connection. If that fails due to a local proxy with a response of 407 (Authorization Required), both try to use locally cached credentials.  Old threat, added in the KB. https://www.welivesecurity.com/2021/06/10/backdoordiplomacy-upgrading- quarian-turian/
Malware.GraphSteel: GraphSteel malware is written in Go, a versatile and cross-platform programming language with minimal footprint and low AV detection rates. The capabilities of this tool cover network reconnaissance, command execution, and file operations. GraphSteel features: 1) Gather hostname, username, and IP address information. 2) Execute commands. 3) steal account credentials. 4) Use WebSocket and GraphQL to communicate with C2 using AES and base64 encryption.  Fake antivirus updates used to deploy Cobalt Strike in Ukraine https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/fake-antivirus-updates- used-to-deploy-cobalt-strike-in-ukraine/

Threat Actors.Hive0107: An affiliate group of Wizard Spider, targeting organizations in the U.S. with Trickbot as well as BazarLoader. Hive0107 / Hive- | Details on Hive-0107 | What can you tell me about Hive 0107? TRICKBOT EXPANDS MALWARE DISTRIBUTION CHANNELS https://duo.com/decipher/trickbot-expandsmalware-distribution-channels
Threat Actors.EGoManiac: EGoManiac is responsible for the previously reported ‘Octopus Brain’ campaign, where the operators interdicted the machines of OdaTV journalists to place malware and incriminating documents, effectively framing them before arrest. On the surface, EGoManiac activity revolves around a Turkish nexus. The malware is riddled with Turkish language, lures are written in Turkish, victims are Turkish and relevant to local politics. The connection to Ahtapot and the OdaTV incident entails the actor’s ability to physically interdict systems within Turkey. Additionally, most PDB paths for Rad components have a root folder of ‘EGM’, from which researchers derived the name ‘EGoManiac’.  | Threat Actor EGo Maniac EGoManiac - An Unscrupulous Turkish-Nexus Threat Actor https://www.sentinelone.com/labs/egomaniac-anunscrupulous-turkish-nexus- threat-actor/
Threat Actors.Stormous Gang: The Stormous ransomware gang is known for website defacement and information theft, represents itself as a group of Arabic-speaking hackers. The group has been active since 2021, and during the Russian-Ukrainian conflict in 2022, it officially announced its support for the Russian government and its intention to target Ukrainian government institutions such as the Ukrainian foreign ministry. The manufacturing sector has been most frequently targeted by the group, organizations of all sizes and sectors are featured on the group’s hit list, including one of India’s largest business conglomerates and a Japanese video game manufacturer. Indiscriminate targeting is likely indicative of a financially - rather than politically - motivated operation that is attempting to raise its profile as quickly as possible and achieve a quick payday.  | Stormous Gang Stormous gang supports Russia https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/22/c/cyberattacks-are-prominent- in-the-russia-ukraineconflict.html
Threat Actors.RedDelta: RedDelta has largely remained unperturbed by the extensive public reporting on its targeting of the Vatican and other Catholic organizations. Despite taking basic operational security measures through changing the resolution status of command and control (C2) domains in the immediate aftermath of this reporting, the group’s tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) remained consistent. RedDelta’s persistence is exemplified through resuming its targeting of both the Vatican and the Catholic Diocese of Hong Kong mail servers. RedDelta continues to operate in line with Chinese strategic priorities.  | TA416 Old threat actor, included in the knowledge base. https://www.recordedfuture.com/reddelta-cyberthreat-operations/
Threat Actors.RED LILI: RED-LILI has launched hundreds of malicious packages as part of node package manager (NPM) attacks on Azure and other developers. RED- | What is RED LILI? RED-LILI continues to launch NPM attacks on Azure developers. scmagazine.com/news/cloud-security/red-lili-continues-to-launch-npm- attacks-on-azure-developers
Threat Actors.UAC0056: The UAC-0056 threat group has been active since at least March 2021. The group was observed attacking government and critical infrastructure organizations in Georgia and Ukraine. UAC-0056’s targets are aligned with the interests of the Russian government, although it is unknown whether it is state-sponsored. UAC-
Threat Actors.EXOTIC LILY: EXOTIC LILY is a resourceful, financially motivated group whose activities appear to be closely linked with data exfiltration and deployment of human-operated ransomware such as Conti and Diavol. At the peak of EXOTIC LILY’s activity, researchers estimate they were sending more than 5,000 emails a day, to as many as 650 targeted organizations globally. Up until November 2021, the group seemed to be targeting specific industries such as IT, cybersecurity, and healthcare, but as of late researchers have seen them attacking a wide variety of organizations and industries, with a less specific focus. EXOTIC LILY / DEV- | Anything on DEV-0413 | What do you know about DEV 0413? | What is DEV0413? Newly discovered threat actor group. https://blog.google/threat-analysis-group/exposing-initial-access-broker-ties- conti/
Threat Actors.Storm Cloud: Storm Cloud is a Chinese threat actor that has been observed targeting Tibetan organizations since at least 2018. The attacks were launched at a very limited subset of visitors to over two dozen different Tibetan websites that Storm Cloud had managed to compromise. Beginning in May 2019, researchers started tracking a new series of strategic web compromises that have been used in highly targeted attacks against Tibetan individuals and organizations by this Chinese APT.  | What is StormCloud? Active threat actor, added in the KB. https://www.volexity.com/blog/2020/03/31/storm-cloud-unleashed-tibetan- community-focus-of-highly-targeted-fake-flash-campaign/
Threat Actors.Scarab: Scarab or UAC-0026 is a Chinese threat actor whose activity was the first public example of a Chinese threat actor targeting Ukraine since the invasion began in February 2022. Scarab has a relatively long history of activity based on open source intelligence. The group was first identified in 2015, while the associated IOCs are archived on OTX. As noted in the previous research, Scarab has operated since at least 2012, targeting a small number of individuals across the world, including Russia, the United States, and others. The backdoor deployed by Scarab in their campaigns is most commonly known as Scieron. Scarab / UAC- | Details on UAC-0026 | Threat actor UAC0026 | Anything on UAC 0026 Chinese Threat Actor Scarab Targeting Ukraine https://www.sentinelone.com/labs/chinese-threat-actor-scarab-targeting- ukraine/
Threat Actors.Muhstik Malware Gang: Muhstik Malware Gang is a threat actor group that delivers the Muhstik botnet malware. The Muhstik malware gang actively targets and exploits a Lua sandbox escape vulnerability in Redis after a proof-of-concept exploit was publicly released. The vulnerability is tracked as CVE-2022-0543 and was discovered in February 2022, affecting both Debian and Ubuntu Linux distributions. The Muhstik botnet is thought to be operated out of China, as researchers have previously linked its control infrastructure to a Chinese forensics firm. It has been around since at least
Threat Actors.SunCrypt: The SunCrypt Ransomware-as-a-Service (RaaS) group appeared in October 2019, advertising their affiliate program on dark web forums. In August 2020, SunCrypt claimed to be a member of the Maze ransomware cartel, although the Maze ransomware group denied any affiliation with SunCrypt. The SunCrypt payload appears to have some code overlap with another ransomware family, QNAPCrypt. Along with encrypting and stealing data, SunCrypt has adopted a third extortion technique: threatening DDoS attacks if the ransom is not paid.  | Information on SunCrypt Ransomware Gang Ransomware group claims responsibility for cyber-attack on metro healthcare organization. https://kfor.com/news/local/ransomware-group-claims-responsibility-for-cyber- attack-on-metro-healthcare-organization/
Threat Actors.Pandora Ransomware Gang: Pandora is a ransomware gang with their own encryptor. It is known for attacking automotive giant DENSO. Pandora ransomware is an operation launched in March
Threat Actors.SharpPanda: SharpPanda is a Chinese advanced persistent (APT) threat actor that has been active since at least 2018 and has reinforced its cyber warfare activities. SharpPanda APT attacks and targets Southeast Asian government users with template injection of malicious documents. The attackers use spear-phishing to gain initial access and leverage old Microsoft Office vulnerabilities together with the chain of in-memory loaders to attempt and install a previously unknown backdoor on the victim’s machines. Upon opening the document, it connects back to the hacker’s server to download the payload file.  | Information on Sharp Panda SharpPanda: Chinese APT Group Targets Southeast Asian Government. https://research.checkpoint.com/2021/chinese-apt-group-targets-southeast- asian-government-with-previously-unknown-backdoor/
Threat Actors.BackdoorDiplomacy: BackdoorDiplomacy is an APT threat actor group, due to the main vertical of its victims, has been targeting Ministries of Foreign Affairs and telecommunication companies in Africa and the Middle East since at least 2017. For initial infection vectors, the group favors exploiting vulnerable internet-exposed devices such as web servers and management interfaces for networking equipment. Once on a system, its operators make use of open-source tools for scanning the environment and lateral movement. Interactive access is achieved in two ways: (1) via a custom backdoor called Turian that is derived from the Quarian backdoor; and (2) in fewer instances, when more direct and interactive access is required, certain open-source remote access tools are deployed. In several instances, the group has been observed targeting removable media for data collection and exfiltration. Finally, both Windows and Linux operating systems have been targeted.  | Threat Actor Backdoor Diplomacy | CloudComputating | What details do you have on Cloud Computating? Old threat actor, active in 2021. Included in the KB. https://www.welivesecurity.com/2021/06/10/backdoordiplomacy-upgrading- quarian-turian/
Threat Actors.TA2721: The group TA2721 targets multiple industries from finance to entertainment. The group uses Spanish-languages lures to distribute a known but infrequently used remote access trojan (RAT) called Bandook. Researchers nicknamed the group Caliente Bandits for their use of Hotmail email accounts “Caliente” which is the Spanish word for “hot.” Researchers began tracking this group in January 2021 and have observed TA2721 distribute email threats delivering Bandook every week since April. The campaigns are low volume, with fewer than 300 messages per campaign. The threats target entities globally, but the threat actors mostly impact individuals with Spanish surnames at these organizations.  | TA 2721 | Who are Caliente Bandits? Threat actor active in 2021, included in the KB. proofpoint.com/us/blog/threat-insight/new-threat-actor-uses-spanish- language-lures-distribute-seldom-observed-bandook
Threat Actors.Pinoy Vendetta: Pinoy Vendetta is a threat actor group originating from the Philippines, so far it is known that one of the members of Pinoy Vendetta was identified as an IT graduate, and he’s based in Davao City. The Pinoy Vendetta hacking group claimed credit for a series of DDoS attacks against critical media, political opposition figures, and the Communist Party of the Philippines (CPP). The group started publicly posting about the DDoS attacks in June 2021. Before that, most of the content of their Facebook page was general cybersecurity news.  NUJP says probe traced cyberattacks on news sites to PH hackers group https://news.abs-cbn.com/news/03/16/22/nujp-says-ph-hackers-group-behind- cyberattacks-on-news-sites
Threat Actors.LokiLocker Ransomware Gang: Ransomware Gang behind RaaS “LokiLocker” suspected to be originating from Iran.  | LokiLocker Gang threat actor New Ransomware Family Identified: LokiLocker RaaS Targets Windows Systems. https://blogs.blackberry.com/en/2022/03/lokilocker-ransomware
Threat Actors.Squad303: Squad303, which uses iconography similar to that of the hacking group Anonymous, has created the tool that allows SMS, WhatsApp and email messages to be sent to randomly selected Russians. The squad says they are an international group of programmers coordinated from Poland. The name comes from an RAF unit of Polish pilots who helped win the Battle of Britain in World War II.  | Threat Actor Squad 303 Hacking group Squad303 creates a tool to send random Russian phones anti- war messages. https://www.newshub.co.nz/home/technology/2022/03/hacking-group- squad303-creates-tool-to-send-random-russian-phones-anti-war-messages. html
Threat Actors.GhostSec: Also known as Ghost Security, the group considers itself a ‘vigilante’ group and was initially formed to target ISIS websites that preach Islamic extremism. Ghostsec is also commonly referred to as an offshoot of Anonymous. It joined sides with Ukraine during the Russian invasion of Ukraine in February 2022.  | What is Ghost Security? Threat actor siding with Ukraine. https://therecord.media/russia-or-ukraine-hacking-groups-take-sides/
Threat Actors.AgainstTheWest: The group is actively working to breach Russian infrastructure including Russian railways and Russian Government contractors. As of March 1st, 2022, the group has issued a new statement for further clarification that they won’t be collaborating with anonymous. Furthermore, that ATW will be splitting into two groups. One for Russia- related breaches, one for Chinese related. ATW accused Anonymous of taking the credit for the work done by ATW. ATW had been suspended from Twitter as of March 3rd, 2022.  | ATW Threat actor siding with Ukraine. https://therecord.media/russia-or-ukraine-hacking-groups-take-sides/
Threat Actors.SHDWsec: SHDWsec is a threat actor group that joined the movement to support Ukraine during the Russian invasion of Ukraine in February 2022. The group works in collaboration with ATW and Anonymous in operations against Russia.  Threat actor siding with Ukraine. https://therecord.media/russia-or-ukraine-hacking-groups-take-sides/
Threat Actors.Belarusian Cyber Partisans: Belarusian Cyber Partisans is a hacktivist threat actor group that supported Ukraine during the Russian invasion of Ukraine. The activist hacking group successfully accessed the computers that control the Belarusian train system, stopping trains in Minsk and Orsha, as well as in the town of Osipovichi. The operation was intended to “slow down the transfer” of Belarus-based Russian troops into Ukraine. The hacktivists have worked against the Belarus government and were able to leak data of secret police archives, lists of alleged police informants, personal information about top government officials and spies, and more.  Threat actor siding with Ukraine. https://therecord.media/russia-or-ukraine-hacking-groups-take-sides/
Threat Actors.KelvinSecurity: Private Information Hacker Company that provides Private Hacker Service for Universal Use, sided with Ukraine during the Russian invasion of Ukraine in February 2022.  Threat actor siding with Ukraine. https://therecord.media/russia-or-ukraine-hacking-groups-take-sides/
Threat Actors.Raidforums2: Raidforums2 supported Ukraine during the Russian invasion of Ukraine. Members actively DDOS-ed Russian websites and attacked Russian infrastructure. They also said to believe the Chinese hacked Ukrainian networks. Previously labeled as Raidforum, the collective is now operating as Raidforums2 after having outage and access issues. It is unclear what went wrong with the original Raidforum.  | Raidforum threat actor Threat actor siding with Ukraine. https://therecord.media/russia-or-ukraine-hacking-groups-take-sides/
Threat Actors.ContiLeaks: Backing Ukraine, during the Russian invasion of Ukraine, the group exposed the infamous ransomware group Conti from the inside out. Since February 27, 2022, following Conti’s statement of Russian support, an account named ContiLeaks leaked hundreds of files containing internal Conti communications. The informant is believed to be Ukrainian and has continued to leak more and more files as days go by. A more recent data set shows communication depicting the chaos within Conti. Actor 1 says, “Hi, all VM farms are cleared and deleted, servers are disabled.” Actor 2 responds, “I deleted all the farms with the shredder and shut down the servers.”  | What is Conti Leaks? Threat actor siding with Ukraine. https://therecord.media/russia-or-ukraine-hacking-groups-take-sides/
Threat Actors.Secjuice: Secjuice stood with Ukraine during the Russian invasion of Ukraine. This collective took a less volatile approach by using open-source intelligence (OSINT) and psychological operations (PsyOps). At the request of IT army of Ukraine, they have created a website for missing persons within Ukraine as a resource for families. In a tweet on March 2nd, 2022, the group asked for assistance in ensuring the website is hosted on a safe server and not vulnerable to attacks.  Threat actor siding with Ukraine. https://therecord.media/russia-or-ukraine-hacking-groups-take-sides/
Threat Actors.Zatoichi: Zatoichi supported Russia during the Russia-Ukraine war in February 2022 through the spread of disinformation via the group’s Twitter account. Among many false claims, the account stated, “Killnet has already put down the Anonymous website, which announced the start of a cyberwar with the Russian government, the Right Sector website, and the website of the President of Ukraine.”  Threat actor siding with Russia. https://therecord.media/russia-or-ukraine-hacking-groups-take-sides/
Threat Actors.Killnet: Killnet supported Russia during the Russia-Ukraine war in February 2022. The group published a video addressing the people of Russia encouraging them to never doubt their country. The video features a hooded figure with a distorted voice claiming to have taken down the website belonging to Anonymous. Little is known about the group and it is unclear as to whether the group existed previously.  Threat actor siding with Russia. https://therecord.media/russia-or-ukraine-hacking-groups-take-sides/
Threat Actors.XakNet: XakNet supported Russia during the Russia-Ukraine war in February 2022. The collective called itself a “team of Russian patriots” in a recent and criticized Anonymous, “We do not hide behind the mask of abstract ‘Anonymous’.” The announcement concludes with a final threat, “For every hack/ddos in our country, similar incidents will occur in Ukraine.”  Threat actor siding with Russia. https://therecord.media/russia-or-ukraine-hacking-groups-take-sides/
Threat Actors.Digital Cobra Gang: Digital Cobra Gang supported Russia during the Russia-Ukraine war in February 2022. They issued a public statement that reads, “DIGITAL COBRA GANG DCG has officially declared cyberwar on hackers who attacking Russia as well and to protect justice. Do you want to invade Russia? Taste the good from the whole WORLD #Ukrainewar #Russia We fight for the Good, 10m deaths and 50 wars Russia? NO!” The group entered the cyberwar via Twitter on February 27th, 2022. The most recent update declares their use of a ‘secret weapon.’ “We set many traps so we have wired 27.918 computers from the guys who attacking Russia and we are ready to drop our secret weapon.”  | DCG Threat actor siding with Russia. https://therecord.media/russia-or-ukraine-hacking-groups-take-sides/
Threat Actors.The Red Bandits: The Red Bandits supported Russia during the Russia-Ukraine war in February 2022. On February 22, the group tweeted, “We’ve hijacked the @UkrainePolice Dashcams and have been watching them. If Ukraine does not do what #Russia wants we will escalate our attacks against Ukraine to involve panic scares. We will also consider distributing #ransomeware in #UkraineRussiaCrisis #RussiaUcraina #Ukraine.” The collective self-identifies as a cybercrime group from Russia, however, it is widely speculated to in fact be Russian Intelligence.  | DCG Threat actor siding with Russia. https://therecord.media/russia-or-ukraine-hacking-groups-take-sides/
Threat Actors.Freecivilian: Freecivilian supported Russia during the Russia-Ukraine war in February 2022. The group reportedly advertised stolen data from 50 different Ukrainian government websites from a February 23, 2022 attack. The attacks on the websites included displayed defacement messages that were almost identical to messages from a January 15, 2022 attack linked to UNC1151. Although claiming to be an independent cybercriminal, many suspect the group is linked to nation-state actors.  Threat actor siding with Russia. https://therecord.media/russia-or-ukraine-hacking-groups-take-sides/
